# **Red Hat Editorial Handbook | Red Hat blog** {#red-hat-editorial-handbook-|-red-hat-blog}

The Red Hat blog publishes content that resonates with an organic search audience of sysadmins, architects, and IT decision-makers. 

Its [objectives](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1RE_EeukfEv87WBkRC7zSYyUu0REFVeYXL_sLbG9zuRU/edit#heading=h.88qt0pr91g8c) are to:

* Grow an audience for Red Hat  
* Guide the audience from unknown to known  
* Do this efficiently with the highest quality and consistency

Examples of blog posts include:

* High level product demos and case studies  
* Tutorials  
* Thought leadership  
* Event summaries and takeaways  
* Interviews  
* Listicles and roundups  
* …and more

Although our primary audience consists of sysadmins, architects and IT decision-makers who are not yet customers, our readers may also be long-time users of Red Hat products, open source enthusiasts, competitors, or C-level prospective customers. We should respect our readers’ time and attention and meet their expectations. However, readers come from different backgrounds and fields of study, and our aim is to educate, so we strive to make no assumptions about expertise or experience. 

Blog posts are not press releases, product pages, data sheets, or technical documentation. Find out more about the different types of content on redhat.com [here](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1TAWPP42Jta0qFuwJc-vNnPijS6yE964dhrgBFF6xKRs/edit).

**We work closely with:**

* [**developers.redhat.com/blog**](http://developers.redhat.com/blog)  
* [**cloud.redhat.com/learn**](http://cloud.redhat.com/learn)  
* **Knowledgebase on [access.redhat.com](http://access.redhat.com)**

**If your content is not accepted for publication on [redhat.com/blog](http://redhat.com/blog), it may be referred to one of these destinations to more effectively engage with the target audience.**

The purpose of this handbook is to enable Red Hat teams and individuals to understand the Red Hat blog’s editorial standards, strategy, and process.

## **Who runs the Red Hat Blog?** {#who-runs-the-red-hat-blog?}

The editorial content team runs the Red Hat blog as part of the Content Team within Brand Experience and Communication (BX+C). We have extensive experience with open source technology, editing, writing, SEO, and marketing. 

* [Deb Richardson](https://rover.redhat.com/people/profile/derichar), Senior Content Strategist  
* [Seth Kenlon](https://rover.redhat.com/people/profile/skenlon), Principal Technical Writer  
* [Isabel Lee](https://rover.redhat.com/people/profile/islee), Marketing Communications Intern  
* [Lauren Pritchett](https://rover.redhat.com/people/profile/lpritche), Manager, Editorial Strategy

Contact all of us at [editorial-team@redhat.com](mailto:editorial-team@redhat.com). You can also join our [Blog Contributors Slack Channel](https://redhat.enterprise.slack.com/archives/C06A5CPTNCR) and [blog-contributors@redhat.com](mailto:blog-contributors@redhat.com) mailing list.

## **10 reasons to contribute to the Red Hat blog** {#10-reasons-to-contribute-to-the-red-hat-blog}

1. Dedicated Drupal support  
2. Support from the PR and social media teams  
3. Streamlined submission template and checklist (keep reading\!)  
4. SEO refinement for each blog post  
5. Relevant linkage within the Red Hat site system to drive engagement and conversions  
6. Localization and translation support  
7. Performance analytics aligned with company goals  
8. Direct connection to editorial coordination  
9. Avoids the potential for duplicate content  
10. Complies with data privacy laws

## **Commitment to editorial standards** {#commitment-to-editorial-standards}

* We follow Red Hat’s [citation style guide](https://source.redhat.com/departments/legal/redhatintellectualproperty/trademarks/trademarks_and_domain_names_wiki/copyright_notices_and_trademark_legends).  
* We follow Red Hat’s [brand standards](https://www.redhat.com/en/about/brand/standards).  
* We follow Red Hat’s [accessibility policy.](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1OqnmnVPeHGdYN-G448vHOfFsCY_JNDJ6W__79clza3Q/edit#heading=h.hkcc51cu8fun)  
* We use Red Hat’s [official product names list](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1DLS_lS3VKidgZIvcLmLp9BoiqptkvqHWfe1D5FD2kfk/edit?gid=1987148185#gid=1987148185).  
* We use the Red Hat blog’s [style guide](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1vEApKSfiVebwHomL7VyFfdEz0N_OxygjjWfb698A91w/edit#heading=h.lvar89rc94v9). If something is not covered in our blog style guide, we use Red Hat’s [corporate style guide](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1UI2wHjF-9uPEo7Dnt-nugQXuIMQUgTQv_QOUXL1x8zE/edit#heading=h.pwof9b6heff).  
* We prioritize blog posts that align with topics and themes that are congruent with business priorities.

## **5 steps to contribute to the Red Hat blog** {#5-steps-to-contribute-to-the-red-hat-blog}

### **Step 1: Plan your blog post**  {#step-1:-plan-your-blog-post}

All blog posts are planned in alignment with the editorial calendar. 

#### Editorial topics and quarterly themes {#editorial-topics-and-quarterly-themes}

Readers trust the Red Hat blog for thought leadership on these topics:

* Application platforms  
* Developer productivity  
* Infrastructure  
* Automation  
* Edge, AI, and emerging technologies  
* People, community, and culture

Quarterly editorial themes drive timeboxed focus on key thought leadership topics, resulting in clear and consistent messaging to Red Hat’s prospects and customers. Themes help contributors and marketers prioritize editorial direction in alignment with [major events](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1pC9eJPNS8fednH9AenaZeC7kLZQZ972iGujHd9u_xkI/edit?gid=1513500815#gid=1513500815), product releases, industry trends, and [corporate strategy](https://source.redhat.com/about_red_hat/corporate_strategy). By targeting 60% alignment, we can consistently amplify Red Hat’s big moments with the flexibility to cover the topics and stories that matter most to our readers.

* Always on: AI, Virtualization  
* Q1: At the edge  
* Q2: RHEL on the cloud  
* Q3: Automation for AI readiness  
* Q4: Application modernization for open hybrid cloud

#### Stakeholder editorial calendars {#stakeholder-editorial-calendars}

We recommend planning blog posts in collaboration with your team or manager to better align with priorities and messaging. Stakeholder groups can use our [spreadsheet template](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1oYw62BukHpdlhH3on4JE6OB8qEaZWm5MCJL1hElWaUk/edit?gid=1979963978#gid=1979963978) to map out quarterly blog post plans. 

The editorial team collaborates with stakeholder groups to:

* Review performance data  
* Brainstorm content ideas, headlines, and topics together  
* Map to priorities and editorial themes  
* Plan content for events, [releases](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1pC9eJPNS8fednH9AenaZeC7kLZQZ972iGujHd9u_xkI/edit?gid=952733233#gid=952733233), moments, etc…  
* Consider publication placement (Red Hat blog, Developers, learning path, customer portal, etc…)

Current editorial stakeholder contacts and calendars

* Thought Leadership  
  * [Tracker: Executive Thought Leadership](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/19PrgQE-BE4BMY7fLBP_uD9lcOo6J2orcyc96LZlr5nc/edit?gid=2101268081#gid=2101268081)  
* AI BU  
  * Will McGrath  
  * [AI Blog Contribution Schedule](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1smvB4P5AXhGbJ5qLhwaRhIqxAq85BDIJDdKkO29iEzw/edit?gid=1979963978#gid=1979963978)  
* Ansible BU

* OpenShift

    * Contact: Dan Russo

#### Considerations for placement {#considerations-for-placement}

There are several placement options for publishing content created by Red Hatters. We use audience insights from user research and performance data to help determine the best placement for content. 

Deep-dive resources:

* [CCS content types](https://source.redhat.com/groups/public/content_design_and_planning/content_types)  
* [Types of content on redhat.com (at a glance)](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1TAWPP42Jta0qFuwJc-vNnPijS6yE964dhrgBFF6xKRs/edit)

Editorial intake placements:

* Red Hat blog  
  * IT decision makers, architects, sysadmins  
  * Thought leadership, high level technical content  
  * Unknown visitors  
* Red Hat Developers blog  
  * Developers, platform engineers  
  * Hands-on content, step-by-step tutorials  
  * Unknown visitors  
  * Cheat sheets, eBooks  
  * Potential for learning path development  
  * [RHD Request Form](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSew64_oRBfHEzDkhM04gsSx3uuNORhNSsvoFacvZou_jhHOVg/viewform)  
* [cloud.redhat.com/learn](http://cloud.redhat.com/learn)  
  * Sysadmins  
  * Technical tutorials  
  * Unknown visitors, early in discover/learn phase  
  * [More information here](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Oi82spdHKq8XLlc5ay0hlIcuqSp6fF87LH9KSGd7Fkk/edit#heading=h.6hscgl80i5yk)  
* [developers.redhat.com/learn](http://developers.redhat.com/learn)  
  * Developers & platform engineers  
  * Technical tutorials  
  * Unknown or known visitors, in learn/evaluate/adopt  
  * More information here [RHD Learning Path roadmap (Author Resources tab for submission details)](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1knRaUSH8ue9VMUpIPXEtaCs2vNjjeyaX_oAHekT-uYg/edit?usp=sharing)   
* Knowledgebase  
  * Recommended for subscriber audience  
  * Option to not require login  
* [PathFactory](https://source.redhat.com/departments/marketing/marketing_technology_and_operations/pathfactory)  
  * Known visitors  
  * Educate about product benefits to nurture toward purchase  
  * Example use case: email  
* External  
  * LinkedIn, Medium, GitHub  
  * Great for trip reports, team updates, personal achievements  
  * Pros include:  
    * Quick time to publish.  
    * Rapidly editable content.  
    * Lightweight process  
  * Cons include:  
    * No or limited ability to track content performance.  
    * Significantly less SEO value when publishing to other domains.  
    * Potential risk that customers encountering unofficial content can lose faith in Red Hat up to, and including, lost deals. (This has happened.)  
    * Without formal Red Hat editing there are also possible legal risks.

### **Step 2: Write your post** {#step-2:-write-your-post}

While you’re planning blog posts with your stakeholder group and editorial team, carve out some time (1-2 hours) to complete the [Writing for Red Hat](https://training-lms.redhat.com/sso/saml/auth/rhlpint?RelayState=deeplinkoffering%3D56373121) course. We recommend taking this course every year. If you’ve taken this course within the last year but need a refresher, check out the [Writing for Red Hat | Takeaway guide](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1tVsQi-Wh3EAdBHOm7QIOhv-vFnkuxDlSBtMybIddIPc/edit#heading=h.66y4kqbj468a). 

The blog’s voice is aligned with the [Red Hat brand](https://www.redhat.com/en/about/brand/standards/personality): open, authentic, helpful, and brave. Our brand voice is experienced, compassionate, and progressive. Our style is clear, concise, conversational, credible, and compelling.

* This:  
  * "Automate any tool across any environment."  
  * "Benefit from an OS that moves with you."    
  * "With us, you’ll never work alone."    
  * "Built with a security-first mindset."  
  * "Industry, Inc. saves 6,000 work hours with automation."  
* Not that:  
  * “Streamline your tech setup."  
  * "Harness the power of an operating system that evolves with your business."  
  * "We drive collaboration for maximum business impact."  
  * "You’ll never have to think about security again."  
  * "Industry, Inc. shifts focus to innovation with automation."

Before you start writing, consider the following questions: 

* Who is the intended audience for this session?  
* What solutions or technologies will be discussed? Make sure that the appropriate product groups are aware of what you’re writing and that the features/capabilities you’re discussing are in a **usable (at least tech preview) state**. If you’re looking to tackle an emerging technology topic, make sure it’s something that aligns to Red Hat’s strategic priorities.  
* What specific tasks or types of work will be addressed?  
* How will you engage? Will there be a tutorial, video, customer or partner story?  
* What will the audience learn, and how will it impact them and their organizations?

The blog team will also be looking for:

* Where else is the information or message in this blog post supported?  
* What is the value of this content to Red Hat? The views expressed in the blog post must align to Red Hat’s corporate mission and values.

Important reminders:

* Make sure the primary audience is clear.   
* Concisely explain what you will write and what the audience will take away from your blog post.  
* Include a clear call to action. After reading your blog post, what do you want readers to do? If your blog post ties to an existing webinar, whitepaper, or other asset, link to it as your **call to action (CTA).** If not, it’s time to be creative\! Is there a free trial, demo, or something else that complements what you’ve written about in your post? When it comes to blog posts tied to events, it’s fine to mention Red Hat’s booth number and the event logistics, but that should not be the primary call to action. **Every blog post** should link through to further materials and content on redhat.com, the site system, or at the very least, Red Hat-affiliated material on external sites (like GitHub or project repos).  
* Use complete sentences (not just bullet points).    
* Review (and have a peer review) your post.   
* Write in the first person.  
* Use sentence-case (we only capitalize proper nouns) in your titles and use [official product names](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1DLS_lS3VKidgZIvcLmLp9BoiqptkvqHWfe1D5FD2kfk/edit?gid=1987148185#gid=1987148185).

Posts will not be accepted if they:

* Appear to be exclusively written by gen AI (read our [tips](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Jy-yemRN4-5djtB1fOGwf9DLyOGXcOIhgwKtqz3l5Fc/edit) on how to use gen AI to augment the writing process)  
* Do not have a call to action  
* Contain jargon  
* Use of other people’s (intellectual) property  
* Are not original content (the Red Hat blog does not republish content that has already been published elsewhere on the Internet, including developers.redhat.com and ibm.com)

Pro-tips:

* Appeal to an unknown audience (not just current customers)  
* Cross-portfolio stories that highlight a customer and/or partner will be prioritized.  
* Focus on user-specific use cases and challenges. High-level solution-oriented, technical content that can help communicate value but doesn’t drill too deeply (unlike technical documentation).  
* Blog posts need to demonstrate your personal experience, your expertise, and your trustworthiness.   
* If your post is not accepted for the Red Hat blog, we may recommend that you submit it for publication on the Red Hat Developers blog or KCS. 

**\>\>\> Pro-tip: Eliminate marketing jargon before you submit your draft. Our blog is a conversation tool with our prospects. You, the author, are a human communicating with another human, the reader.  \<\<\<**

Readers crave authentic content. They prefer high-level solution-oriented, technical content that can help communicate value but doesn’t drill too deeply (unlike technical documentation).

Readers (and Google) crave [authentic content](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1von--aXLfhQ_tdTK9ejIN-mSGztY6tCLB2RIhiWOdis/edit?pli=1#slide=id.g27834f16cc8_2_6) that demonstrates:

* Your personal experience  
* Your expertise  
* Your trustworthiness

#### Writing cheat sheet {#writing-cheat-sheet}

- [ ] Is this a topic that is valuable to Red Hat and our customers?  
- [ ] Is this a topic that should be talked about right now?  
- [ ] Am I an appropriate person to be writing about this topic?  
- [ ] Who, outside my immediate organization, might need to be aware of or review my post?  
- [ ] Do I have a clear point to make in my post?  
- [ ] Do I have a clear call to action for readers?  
- [ ] Am I prepared with my own promotion plan for internal and social media channels?  
- [ ] Am I comfortable with the editorial process?

#### How to create an outline for your blog post {#how-to-create-an-outline-for-your-blog-post}

The editorial team created a library of templates ([12 blog article templates you can steal today](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1bxDQUIn84XxaX6CMiNzvoHU9-clLSpouiun5q0rzYxE/edit#heading=h.y4ud5n5drxuy)) that you can use to outline your blog post. 

Generally, there are 3 key steps to outline your blog post:

1. Write one sentence describing the problem your blog post solves. For example, "How to use Ansible Automation Platform to keep your container images updated" or "Follow these 5 best practices to stay compliant with your organization’s security policies".  
2. Write down the three most important points your blog post needs to convey. If you have more than three items, you probably have enough content for a mini-series\!\*  
3. Now go back to the top. Write two or three paragraphs under each statement.

When you’re finished, write a title for your blog post at the bottom of the page, and then copy and paste the first paragraph of the blog post under it.

Here’s what you’ve just done:

* Established a thesis statement  
* Written SEO-friendly subheadings  
* Provided just the vital information about your topic

Readers typically don’t scroll down a page for more than 500 to 1,000 words. If you feel you have more to say about your topic, you probably have at least one more blog post to write. Open a new document and start fresh, continuing seamlessly from your first blog post.

##### A note on series {#a-note-on-series}

There are two primary ways to write a series:

1. Write and submit the series at the same time. Inform the editorial team that you are submitting a series. That way, the editorial team will schedule the publication dates and interlink the blog posts accordingly. This is the ideal approach for a lengthy tutorial, use case, or customer story. Here’s an example of a series that was submitted all at once:

   [Resolve issues before customers notice them with Red Hat and Dynatrace](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/resolve-issues-customers-notice-them-red-hat-and-dynatrace)  
   [Quickly identify and automatically remediate issues in your IT environment](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/quickly-identify-and-automatically-remediate-issues-your-it-environment)  
   [Bring value to Day 0 and Day 1 operations with Red Hat and Dynatrace](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/bring-value-day-0-and-day-1-operations-red-hat-and-dynatrace)  
   [Scaling up with AI and out to the edge with Red Hat and Dynatrace](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/scaling-ai-and-out-edge-red-hat-and-dynatrace)

2. Write and submit blog posts individually. This approach works well for explaining concepts or related tutorials. These posts are not necessarily in chronological order or dependent on one another. 

Each blog post is a potential entry point and first impression of Red Hat. As always, make the first paragraph engaging to draw the reader in. Give them a reason to spend time on the article—"What's in it for me?" 

We never promise an upcoming blog post to our readers unless we have it in hand and scheduled in Drupal. 

#### How long should my blog post be?  {#how-long-should-my-blog-post-be?}

We don't worry too much about word count, and neither should you. Write just long enough to make your point and engage readers.

However, if having a word count helps you structure your writing, here are a few guidelines:

**500-600 words:** Around 500 words might be all you need to provide a project update, announce a new conference, or share other timely news.

**Example:**  

* [What is Ansible Automation Hub and why should you use it?](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/what-ansible-automation-hub-and-why-should-you-use-it) (\~580 words, \~$2m opp value in prev 12 months)

**600-800 words:** For reference, a 1-2 page print magazine blog post is around 750 words (1 page without images, 2 pages if it includes several images and/or screenshots). This is a good range for a regular feature blog post, column submission, interview, or roundup. Consider adding a sub-head or two to break up the text and walk readers through sections of the blog post.

**Example:**

* [Career builders: Upskill in the new year with these 10 free Red Hat Training webinars](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/career-builders-upskill-new-year-these-10-free-red-hat-training-webinars) (\~650 words, \~12,850 UVs and \~$1.25m opp value in \~7 months)

**800-1,300 words:** How-tos, getting-started guides, tutorials, and more thorough roundups that go a little more in-depth tend to be longer than feature blog posts.

**Example:**

* [How to create and use a Red Hat Satellite manifest](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/how-create-and-use-red-hat-satellite-manifest) (\~1000 words and \*loads\* of screenshots, \~$5m opp value in prev 12 months)

**1,300-2,000 words:** In-depth blog posts that cover a wide swath of a topic, or an extensive tutorial.

**Examples:**

* [What is AI/ML and why does it matter to your business?](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/what-aiml-and-why-does-it-matter-your-business) (\~2,000 words, also our top-performing blog post for SEO with over 25,000 Google clicks in prev 12 months)  
* [Introducing the Red Hat Universal Base Image](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/introducing-red-hat-universal-base-image) (\~1450 words, top performing blog post overall)

**Multipart blog posts:** If your blog post is much longer than 2,000 words, we will probably ask you to break it up into multiple parts.

***Linking [this template library](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1bxDQUIn84XxaX6CMiNzvoHU9-clLSpouiun5q0rzYxE/edit#heading=h.y4ud5n5drxuy) here again in case you didn’t already open it in another tab while reading this exciting documentation\!*** 

#### Examples of different types of blog posts {#examples-of-different-types-of-blog-posts}

Here are some high quality examples of the various types of blog posts we generally publish on the blog. 

**Product announcements**

Product announcements are generally written and published by PR from the various business units.

* [Introducing the Red Hat Universal Base Image](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/introducing-red-hat-universal-base-image)

**Product tutorials**

* [How to automate upgrades before RHEL 7 end of maintenance](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/how-automate-upgrades-rhel-7-end-maintenance)

**Technical content**

* [Tekton vs. Jenkins: What's better for CI/CD pipelines on Red Hat OpenShift?](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/tekton-vs-jenkins-whats-better-cicd-pipelines-red-hat-openshift)  
* [What's EPEL, and how do I use it?](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/whats-epel-and-how-do-i-use-it)

**Thought leadership**

* [The State of Kubernetes Security in 2023](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/state-kubernetes-security-2023)  
* [What is AI/ML and why does it matter to your business?](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/what-aiml-and-why-does-it-matter-your-business)  
* [Generative AI: How it can be applied to business applications today](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/generative-ai-business-applications)

**Industry and company news**

Company news is generally managed by the PR team.

* [Red Hat Summit 2023 session catalog and agenda builder now available](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/red-hat-summit-2023-session-catalog-and-agenda-builder-now-available)

**Blog posts about upstream projects**

* [How the Kepler project is working to advance environmentally-conscious efforts](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/how-kepler-project-working-advance-environmentally-conscious-efforts)

**Event summaries and takeaways**

* [Future of observability: KubeCon North America and Observability Day sessions you can't miss](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/kubecon-north-america-and-observability-day)

**Listicles**

* [10 Linux commands for Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS users](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/linux-commands-for-rosa-users)  
* [21 things every Red Hat Satellite user should know](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/21-things-every-red-hat-satellite-user-should-know)  
* [4 use cases for AI in cyber security](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/4-use-cases-ai-cyber-security)

**Roundups**

* [Press play: Our top 10 podcast and video episodes in 2023](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/top-10-podcast-video-episodes-2023)  
* [Career builders: Upskill in the new year with these 10 free Red Hat Training webinars](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/career-builders-upskill-new-year-these-10-free-red-hat-training-webinars)

#### 10 headline devices that actually work {#10-headline-devices-that-actually-work}

What is \[PRODUCT/TOPIC\] and why does it matter for your business?

* [What is AI/ML and why does it matter to your business?](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/what-aiml-and-why-does-it-matter-your-business)  
* [What is InstructLab and how do you use it? 9 quick videos to help you get started](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/what-is-instructlab)  
* [What is RHEL AI? A guide to the open source way for doing AI](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/what-rhel-ai-guide-open-source-way-doing-ai)

\[X\] vs \[Y\]: What's the difference?

* [RHEL vs. RHEL AI: What's the difference?](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/rhel-vs-rhel-ai-whats-difference)

X business benefits of \[PRODUCT/TOPIC\]

* [5 reasons to choose Podman in 2025](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/5-reasons-choose-podman-2025)

X \[PRODUCT/TOPIC\] business use cases and real-world examples

* [4 use cases for AI in cyber security](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/4-use-cases-ai-cyber-security)

\[PRODUCT/TOPIC\]: FAQs from the field

* [Red Hat OpenShift Virtualization: FAQs from the field](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/red-hat-openshift-virtualization-faqs)

How to \[do something\] with \[product\] 

* [How to use YAML with InstructLab](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/how-use-yaml-instructlab)  
* [How to prepare your RHEL server for an in-place upgrade](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/how-prepare-your-rhel-server-place-upgrade)

X articles about \[PRODUCT/TOPIC\] you may have missed

* [11 Red Hat AI videos you may have missed](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/11-red-hat-ai-videos-you-may-have-missed)  
* [10 Linux blog posts to bookmark now](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/top-10-linux-articles-2024)

\[Discussion topic\]: An interview with \[someone\]

\[PRODUCT/TOPIC\] explained in plain terms

* [YAML explained for Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS (ROSA) users](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/yaml-explained-for-rosa-users)  
* [OpenShift Virtualization: Not as scary as it seems](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/openshift-virtualization-not-scary-it-seems)

Quote Roundup

* [5 reasons Red Hatters are excited about InstructLab](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/5-reasons-red-hatters-are-excited-about-instructlab)  
* [Get ready for Red Hat Summit 2025: What past speakers want you to know](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/get-ready-red-hat-summit-2025-what-past-speakers-want-you-know)

#### Co-authoring with a partner or customer {#co-authoring-with-a-partner-or-customer}

A partner or customer who wishes to author or co-author a blog post can do so with a Red Hatter’s help. If they are the sole author, a Red Hatter must be able to vouch for them and submit the post on their behalf. We can’t accept submissions from non-Red Hatters. 

Send the partner's author info directly to editorial-team@redhat.com so we can set up their author page. Here is the info we need:

* Author Name: As preferred  
* Author Title: Business card title / title used publicly \+ Company name  
* Author bio: 200 words or fewer  
* Author Profile Photo (at least 300x300 pixels)   
* Pronouns (Optional)  
* LinkedIn Profile URL (Optional)  
* GitHub Profile URL (Optional)

Red Hat authors should have taken the Writing for Red Hat course and be familiar with this handbook. Here are some key reminders that are especially relevant to partner co-authored pieces:

* The content is original. We do not republish content. This means if a partner publishes a post on their own blog, we will not publish the same post on the Red Hat blog.  
* The post is telling a story and is not just an announcement. Ask yourself, what's in it for the reader?   
* Avoid marketing jargon. Avoid hyperbole and unsupported claims.  
* We can include links to the partner's website, but the primary CTA needs to be something from the Red Hat site system (e.g. webinar, learning path, product trial, etc...

Any approvals required by the partner's company are obtained before you submit it through Workfront. 

We’ll tag PR for a final review before publication.

### **Step 3: Submit your post** {#step-3:-submit-your-post}

Now that you’ve planned your post in alignment with the editorial calendar and started your writing journey, you are ready to submit your post. Yay\! Check out our [submission formatting guide](#submission-formatting-guide) at the end of this document for more information specific to formatting code, keywords, tables, etc… 

The total turnaround time from submission to publication is **typically 4-6 weeks** depending on the scope of edits or reviews. After you submit your blog post, it will be reviewed within 2 weeks by the intake team. Then, it goes through our editing process which takes another 2-4 weeks depending on the scope of editing, how quickly the author responds to their editor, PR approval, and the current publishing queue. The more complete your blog post is prior to submission, the more likely it will be published sooner.

**Step Zero: [Plan](#step-1:-plan-your-blog-post) your blog post with your stakeholder group and editorial team**

1. Write your blog post using the [blog template](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1my7gbY0USazBvK_J9RWOKw2xtQj85gkenmR-9uQSWf0/edit#)  
2. Complete [Request Access to Workfront](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe9C4OA4KS0L0db2PcuKxKCFMSqT9g-rTYc3YoBwlBHnjqb-Q/viewform) form if you don’t already have access.   
3. Submit your blog post using this Workfront request [form](https://redhat.my.workfront.com/requests/new?activeTab=tab-new-helpRequest&projectID=6512f72900190b3c6aa8beae18734f6e&path=657a0c1000a1772dc84498f277e9d49d). Here’s a [preview](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Ei4boHpYMLWyvTlqAN8YHesw-7qzL5sM0RKhZBt4kG4/edit#heading=h.nwg9eavj8ei7) of what the request form looks like including our editorial oath\!   
4. Your blog post is reviewed by the intake team on Tuesdays.  
5. If accepted for publication on the Red Hat blog, it is added to the publication schedule. Follow the progress of your accepted submission in the Workfront Red Hat Blog Publishing Schedule [dashboard](https://experience.adobe.com/#/@redhat/so:redhat-Production/workfront/dashboard/6581defb002fbdd785a75229bca18ee3/detail).  
6. Your blog post is edited by the editorial team  
7. Editorial team confirms approval from the necessary parties  
8. Editorial team schedules for publication 

#### How will my blog post be reviewed? {#how-will-my-blog-post-be-reviewed?}

A cross-functional team reviews all submissions on Tuesdays during our intake meeting. This team includes the Red Hat blog, Red Hat Developers, Learning Paths, product docs, [collateral](https://source.redhat.com/departments/marketing/marketing-content-team/marketing_content_team_wiki/collateral_process_documentation), SEO consultants, and messaging consultants. If your blog post is declined for the Red Hat blog, we might refer it to another program. Our team may also offer suggestions to improve the blog post so that it aligns with our priorities and strategy. 

**You should expect edits.** Edits aren’t indicative of bad writing or a bad topic\! Our team is laser-focused on the Red Hat blog editorial voice and standards. 

It’s also possible that additional reviewers may be required, **especially if your blog post is around a sensitive topic, like security or data privacy.** This can include additional subject matter experts (SMEs) from other groups, like Product Security, as well as reviewers from the legal team.

Reminder: Any post that is written by generative AI will be sent back to the author for revisions. We avoid writing content with gen AI because it could harm our SEO and trust with readers. If you’re using gen AI to help you write your post, check out our guide to [Using gen AI for content: Dos and Don'ts](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Jy-yemRN4-5djtB1fOGwf9DLyOGXcOIhgwKtqz3l5Fc/edit#heading=h.fnn0wi9t0p5d)

### **Step 4: Promote your post** {#step-4:-promote-your-post}

You should already have a promotion plan for your blog post before you submit it because we planned together during step 1\. The editorial, PR, and social media teams will provide some limited promotion of Red Hat blog posts. 

**The most effective way to promote your blog post is to share it on [Employee Advocacy](https://redhat.advocacy.sproutsocial.com/current).**

* Add your blog post to Red Hat’s internal, SSO-enabled advocacy tool, [Employee Advocacy](https://redhat.advocacy.sproutsocial.com/current) (EA)   
  * *Pro tips:*   
    * *Review the [Employee Advocacy source page](https://source.redhat.com/departments/marketing/brand_experience_and_communications/socialmediaatredhat/employee_advocacy) for how-tos, best practices, approved images for use, etc.*  
    * *Having issues accessing EA? Reach out to [socialmedia@redhat.com](mailto:socialmedia@redhat.com).*   
    * *Re-submit your story after a few weeks to continue promotion on social media*  
* If you would like to see your blog post considered for Red Hat-branded social media channels, use the [Corporate Repository ‘Content Submission’](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1kzyrrenKLP-GIoGJQcl5QCI6xruVXXppNYlFHlnSBTQ/edit?gid=995523118#gid=995523118) tab  
  * *Pro tip: Be sure to tag [socialmedia@redhat.com](mailto:socialmedia@redhat.com) in a comment* 

Use this [guide](https://docs.google.com/document/d/159__350WH1pAPbxomGhOZ6QqyeOOCcoxrvP3Q-Q-cYs/edit#heading=h.i1yxxol0mkzl) on organic promotion for your content. Another possibility is to include it in an internal newsletter or discussion thread, a LinkedIn post, or sharing the post across your personal and community-affiliated social media handles. If it’s something that customers or prospects need to know, like how to use new RHEL commands to address pain points, it may be worth flagging it to sales enablement or specific account teams.

If you’re unsure what promotion would look like, ask the communications teams\! The [Internal Communications team](http://red.ht/talktoredhatters) along with the PR and Social Media teams can help you think through what promotion is and what you can do yourself to amplify your post.

### **Step 5: Measure your blog post** {#step-5:-measure-your-blog-post}

The editorial team measures blog post performance by a few different KPIs. We source the metrics from the Site System Inventory ([red.ht/site-system-inventory](http://red.ht/site-system-inventory)) which is built using the [Marketing Touched Page Value Model](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1C4wafxVXQ10tXso2bwOR8h8W9MBcBbI3ijNuIxx50q8/edit#slide=id.g2223c919cb7_0_1959). If you don’t have access to Tableau, an export of our monthly metrics is maintained in this spreadsheet: [Red Hat Blog Health Check](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1zhoBWL8dd7vq_x6bwj30V086tRm4gt6H30q9ypgJuTs/edit?gid=920737092#gid=920737092). Here are our KPIs:

* **Google Clicks**: Helps us understand how well the blog post is optimized for organic search for the target keyword. Our hypothesis is that blog posts optimized for keywords with high search volume will get more Google Clicks.  
* **Unique Visitors**: Helps us understand how well the blog post resonates with Red Hat Blog’s intended audience. Our hypothesis is that blog posts with a high volume of unique visitors are reaching our audience.  
* **Opportunity Value**: This is a leading indicator of the potential value of inquiries. Opportunity Value is the estimated SYB value based on the Marketing Touched Page Value Model.  
* **Won Value**: We use this lagging indicator to analyze the quality of the inquiries the Red Hat Blog is generating for the business. Won Value is the actual SYB value based on the Marketing Touched Page Value Model. Our hypothesis is that blog posts with a high won value attract inquiries that are valuable to the business. 

## **Additional resources for contributors and editors** {#additional-resources-for-contributors-and-editors}

### **Submission formatting guide** {#submission-formatting-guide}

If you use the  [Marketing | Blog template](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1my7gbY0USazBvK_J9RWOKw2xtQj85gkenmR-9uQSWf0/edit#), the majority of basic formatting is taken care of for you, but we have a few additional requests.

#### Use good document design principles {#use-good-document-design-principles}

The idea here is to avoid the "wall of text" problem that tends to drive away readers and bury your message.

Unstructured text is dense and hard to read, so make ample use of headings, whitespace and formatting to help readers better navigate and parse your blog post.

* **Use cascading headings to structure your text** (h2, h3, h4, etc.)  
  * *Do not use h1s* \-- those are reserved for page titles and are automatically created by Drupal.  
* **Use formatting to help information stand out**  
  * Make use of things like bold text, italics, and indents to set important information apart.  
  * Do not use underlined text. On the web, underlined text generally denotes hyperlinks and tends to confuse readers.  
* **Show as well as tell**  
  * Use images like charts and graphs, infographics, timelines, and screenshots to illustrate and reinforce your message where it makes sense.  
  * But not too many—overwhelming a blog post with too many images can work against you in terms of readability and pageload speeds.  
  * We generally encourage ***no more than 10 images in a blog post***, with some exceptions for things like tutorials and walkthroughs.

#### Design tips {#design-tips}

* [Bring clarity with these document design tips](https://technicallywewrite.com/2023/08/02/docdesign)

#### Code snippets and keywords {#code-snippets-and-keywords}

We *love* getting technical content, especially stuff with code snippets that readers can learn from and copy/paste to try out for themselves. 

In the past the Blog team requested that code be indicated with backticks and other Markdown-friendly markup.

***Please do not use backticks any more***. We just have to delete them, and it gets confusing and error-prone when there are lots of them in a blog post.

Instead, please just simply format your code with a monospace font, as below. This makes it very simple for us to copy/paste into Drupal, and it's clear to us which parts are code and which aren't.

$ sudo usermod \-a \-G weldr $USER     \# Note: You’ll need to log out and back in for this to take effect.  
$ sudo systemctl enable \--now cockpit.socket  
$ sudo systemctl enable \--now osbuild-composer.socket  
$ sudo firewall-cmd \--add-service=cockpit && sudo firewall-cmd \--add-service=cockpit \--permanent  
success  
success  
$ source /etc/bash\_completion.d/composer-cli  
$ composer-cli status show  
API server status:  
    Database version:   0  
    Database supported: true  
    Schema version:     0  
    API version:        1  
    Backend:            osbuild-composer  
    Build:              NEVRA:osbuild-composer-76-2.el9\_2.2.x86\_64

These will be automatically formatted using CSS to look like this:

![][image1]

Similarly, for keywords or code snippets you're including inline, please use a monospace font.

#### Tables {#tables}

You are welcome to include tables in your posts as long as they are actually being used as tables, *not as some form of formatting hack*.

Also, please keep your table formatting as simple as possible in the Google Doc, like so:

| Id. | CWE-699 category | Count of records |
| :---- | :---- | :---- |
| 1 | [Resource Management Errors](https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/399.html) | 1,866 |
| 2 | [Memory Buffer Errors](https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/1218.html) | 1,749 |
| 3 | [Numeric Errors](https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/189.html) | 867 |

These will be automatically formatted with CSS to look like this:

![][image2]

These formatted tables have lovely extra features that highlight rows and columns on mouseover:

![][image3]

Please, please do not use tables for anything other than to create actual tables. 

#### Pre-submission checklist {#pre-submission-checklist}

- [ ] Post was proposed as part of the quarterly editorial plan 

- [ ] Post has gone through SME/technical reviews

- [ ] Security-related posts have been reviewed by someone on the Security team

- [ ] If post includes analyst mentions, it has been cleared by AR / analyst firm for publication

- [ ] All included images are created and owned by Red Hat and any people visible in photos have given permission

- [ ] Alt text is provided for all images (in a comment, or as *red italics* below the image)

### **Staff editors’ checklists** {#staff-editors’-checklists}

This [style guide](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1vEApKSfiVebwHomL7VyFfdEz0N_OxygjjWfb698A91w/edit) is for staff editors, contract editors, and contributing editors. Contributing authors are not required to read this, but all word nerds are welcome to peruse it\!

Supplementary documentation:

* [Brand Standards](https://www.redhat.com/en/about/brand/standards)  
* [Red Hat corporate style guide | Updated Sep. 12, 2024](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1UI2wHjF-9uPEo7Dnt-nugQXuIMQUgTQv_QOUXL1x8zE/edit#heading=h.pwof9b6heff)  
* [Official Red Hat product names list](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1DLS_lS3VKidgZIvcLmLp9BoiqptkvqHWfe1D5FD2kfk/edit)  
* [\[v7\] Write how real people talk](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1NGw9WWbLm430llFdmTA7b33s4S8jCo3x5w9WfGzKV24/edit#heading=h.dsg98399apem)

#### Technical Editor initial review {#technical-editor-initial-review}

* Run plagiarism check  
* Review author’s background to determine their expertise on the topic audience  
* Review for tone, language, and word usage  
* Review for quality and technical accuracy  
* Review for Red Hat congruence  
* Review the links and any citations

#### Technical Editor copy editing {#technical-editor-copy-editing}

* All inline (in a paragraph) commands, modules, flags, etc. are styled as code consistent with the style guide  
* If the text following a colon is a full sentence, the first letter after the colon is capitalized.  
* Enforce ~~serial/~~Oxford commas: No ifs, ands or buts.  
* No curly single or double quotes: Only straight single and double quotes.  
* Clauses aren’t marked with single dashes or double dashes. Em dashes only.  
* All file extension types are handled the same in that blog post. It’s a .pdf and .jpg or it’s a PDF and JPG.  
* All headers are sentence case.  
* Check Source to make sure there’s no unwanted \<span\> or style tags.  
* Quotes are accurate and linked to an original source. Flag the team if a quote cannot be attributed.  
* All acronyms are defined on first mention.  
* The author is not speaking for the reader: Most voice is “you” or “I” rather than “we” (unless you can specifically identify who “we” applies to, such as the team working on a project)

#### SEO editing checklist {#seo-editing-checklist}

A more detailed checklist can be found in the [Web Optimization Cheatsheet](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1byalHClsyEHAsOUT0kdGfvCiMt9zHuRM_wGt4BLeWdY/edit#heading=h.x0ycz6bze2ia).

* Required: Headline: Relevant keywords, keywords frontloaded, good length  
* Required: Hero Image  
* Required: URL slug includes keywords and is descriptive yet short. Be mindful of duplicate URLs  
* Required: Correct author account is associated  
* Required: Blog Post Category   
* Required: First paragraph: Describes what blog post is about, not just prose (this is likely already done prior to 2nd editor review)  
* Required: Review all links (remove ones not needed, remove ones we aren’t sure of)  
* Required for inline images: All have alt tags  
  * If an author hasn't provided alt text for images, send it back and have them add it  
* Required: Call to action  
* Almost Always: Link to relevant resource in first instance (Preferably a redhat.com page)  
* Almost Always: Appropriate H2 and H3 headers every 2-4 paragraphs.  
* Optional: Relevant blog posts or articles within the same series.

#### Managing editor checklist {#managing-editor-checklist}

* Title and headings use sentence case  
* Dateline matches scheduled publication date  
* Author page is live on production ([https://www.redhat.com/en/authors/name](https://www.redhat.com/en/authors/name))  
* Link to product or topic page on the first instance  
* All links are working and correct  
* Images are placed correctly from the media library  
* No placeholder text  
* All product names adhere to [Official Red Hat product names list (OPL)](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1DLS_lS3VKidgZIvcLmLp9BoiqptkvqHWfe1D5FD2kfk/edit?gid=1987148185#gid=1987148185)  
* Relevant keep exploring menu is added  
* Double check topic and product taxonomies

## **FAQs** {#faqs}

### **Q: How do I get access to Workfront?** {#q:-how-do-i-get-access-to-workfront?}

Complete and submit a [Workfront request form](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe9C4OA4KS0L0db2PcuKxKCFMSqT9g-rTYc3YoBwlBHnjqb-Q/viewform). Email Tracey Lovie for help getting your Workfront account set up. 

### **Q: I just want to write a simple blog post. Why is the publication process so extensive?**  {#q:-i-just-want-to-write-a-simple-blog-post.-why-is-the-publication-process-so-extensive?}

The purpose of the blog is to build an audience for Red Hat, guide readers from unknown to known, and do this efficiently with a commitment to quality and consistency. We require all contributors to abide by the editorial standards documented in this handbook. Editorial standards are important to maintain consistency with the Red Hat brand, build trust with our readers, and comply with legal requirements. The blog team’s responsibility is to uphold editorial standards in service to our readers and customers.

**Pro-tip: Take the [Writing for Red Hat](https://training-lms.redhat.com/sso/saml/auth/rhlpint?RelayState=deeplinkoffering%3D56373121) course\! It is well worth the 1-2 hours of investment to set your blog post up for success.**

### **Q: I’m writing a blog post about a product, customer, partner, or vertical. Who should I make sure reviews my draft before I submit it to the editorial team?** {#q:-i’m-writing-a-blog-post-about-a-product,-customer,-partner,-or-vertical.-who-should-i-make-sure-reviews-my-draft-before-i-submit-it-to-the-editorial-team?}

Any blog post mentioning a customer must be approved by the customer reference team. You can use the [customer reference dashboard](https://lookerstudio.google.com/u/0/reporting/88ef0e6e-942a-42cc-a168-15f5a1fe7a55/page/h2gJD) or email [customer-reference@redhat.com](mailto:customer-reference@redhat.com). For additional reviewers, check out this list:  [Red Hat blog reviewers ](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1npVlQ-rlv5l3-aeuzzZ_3oTU9ueA9Gr66i0xVJUUzGo/edit?tab=t.0)

### **Q: Can a partner or customer submit a blog post?** {#q:-can-a-partner-or-customer-submit-a-blog-post?}

Yes\! There is no better way to demonstrate Red Hat’s value to readers than directly from our partners and customers\! Blog posts can be solely authored by a customer or partner or co-authored with a Red Hatter. Read these [instructions](#co-authoring-with-a-partner-or-customer) for a successful partner or customer-authored blog post. 

### 

### **Q: Why was my submission declined for publication on the Red Hat blog?** {#q:-why-was-my-submission-declined-for-publication-on-the-red-hat-blog?}

Blog posts that are strategically planned as part of our quarterly editorial calendar and meet editorial standards are likely to be accepted for publication.

Most of the time, if your blog post is rejected for publication on the Red Hat blog, it means it is probably a better fit for one of our other publications such as the Red Hat Developers blog, a learning path, or the knowledgebase. That’s because we prioritize publishing content in the right place, for the right audience, at the right time. We work closely with our content partners to connect you to the proper point of contact.

We will reject a blog post submission for publication if it:

* Uses generative AI to write the content  
* Misses the target audience  
* Does not have a clear call to action  
* Contains product marketing jargon  
* Is not optimized for organic search  
* Is repetitive or redundant to a previously published piece (including blog post, press release, article, solution page, etc…)

If your blog post submission is rejected for publication, we recommend the following publication options:

* [PathFactory](https://source.redhat.com/departments/marketing/marketing_technology_and_operations/pathfactory) (recommended for known visitors to educate about product benefits to nurture toward purchase)  
* LinkedIn, Medium, or GitHub

Resource: [Governance on creating net new public-facing web domains/properties](https://source.redhat.com/departments/marketing/digital_experience_system/standards)

### **Q: How can I make sure my blog post will perform well?** {#q:-how-can-i-make-sure-my-blog-post-will-perform-well?}

	Your blog post will be more likely to perform well if it:

* Answers a question people ask Google  
* Helps people understand the technology  
* Includes a partner or customer reference  
* Is opinionated and authentic  
* Is connected to an editorial theme, high priority campaign / event / product announcement and has a promotional plan

  Planning blog posts together in advance also helps to make sure your post will be published at the right time, in the right place, for the right audience. Please meet with the editorial team to schedule quarterly editorial calendar planning with your team.

Here are some tools and templates to use when planning and writing your blog post:

[12 blog article templates you can steal today](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1bxDQUIn84XxaX6CMiNzvoHU9-clLSpouiun5q0rzYxE/edit#heading=h.y4ud5n5drxuy)

[Using gen AI for content: Dos and Don'ts](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Jy-yemRN4-5djtB1fOGwf9DLyOGXcOIhgwKtqz3l5Fc/edit)

[Web content optimization checklist summary](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1byalHClsyEHAsOUT0kdGfvCiMt9zHuRM_wGt4BLeWdY/edit#heading=h.x0ycz6bze2ia)

	[Organic Promotion Guide for Red Hatters](https://docs.google.com/document/d/159__350WH1pAPbxomGhOZ6QqyeOOCcoxrvP3Q-Q-cYs/edit#heading=h.i1yxxol0mkzl)

### **Q: I want to edit my existing blog post. What should I do?** {#q:-i-want-to-edit-my-existing-blog-post.-what-should-i-do?}

Email [editorial-team@redhat.com](mailto:editorial-team@redhat.com) with the nature of your edits. Depending on the scope, we will recommend one of the following actions:

* Send us the URL and the revisions. The best way to do this is to copy the content from the blog post and paste it into a Google Doc. Use “Suggesting” mode to apply the edits. We will update the blog post.   
* Write and submit a new blog post to either publish as a new URL or to replace the existing URL with a new publication date


### **Q: I found a bug on the blog. What should I do?** {#q:-i-found-a-bug-on-the-blog.-what-should-i-do?}

Submit a ticket using help.redhat.com describing the issue. You can also ask for help with Drupal in the [\#help-uxe-me-rhdc](https://redhat.enterprise.slack.com/archives/C05T6MQTUP5) Slack channel.

### **Q: Can I use generative AI tools to write my draft?** {#q:-can-i-use-generative-ai-tools-to-write-my-draft?}

See [Red Hat’s policy](https://source.redhat.com/departments/legal/legal_wiki/policy_on_the_use_of_ai_technology) on the use of AI tools. Generative AI tools are not as good at writing as you are. Trust us\! If the editorial team finds that your submission has been exclusively written with generative AI, we will ask you to rewrite the submission. We’ve developed best practices for how to use gen AI tools to augment the writing process. Check them out here: [Using gen AI for content: Dos and Don'ts](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Jy-yemRN4-5djtB1fOGwf9DLyOGXcOIhgwKtqz3l5Fc/edit)

### **Q: Can I find out how many page views my blog post gets?** {#q:-can-i-find-out-how-many-page-views-my-blog-post-gets?}

You can check your blog post stats in our [Red Hat Blog Health Check](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1zhoBWL8dd7vq_x6bwj30V086tRm4gt6H30q9ypgJuTs/edit#gid=920737092). The primary KPIs measured in the health check are Unique Visitors, Google Clicks, Marketing Touched Opportunity Value, and Marketing Touched Won Value. The health check is updated monthly. The previous month’s data will be populated approximately 3 weeks after the month ends. For example, January numbers will be available around the week of February 21\. 

Our health check is pulled from the site system inventory in Tableau which can be accessed using this link: [red.ht/site-system-inventory](http://red.ht/site-system-inventory) (Make sure you’re on the VPN)

### **Q: Will my blog post be translated? Can I publish a post in my native language?** {#q:-will-my-blog-post-be-translated?-can-i-publish-a-post-in-my-native-language?}

	 [Blog post localization process](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1gKbDf9747f2mvSdWRNJYTbTbEH8SKjbBtp8VWyKQfL4/edit#heading=h.l4axz7oss0tp)

### **Q: Do you take community content?** {#q:-do-you-take-community-content?}

As the corporate blog for an open source company, we know that upstream is critical to Red Hat’s ultimate success as well as the open source community at large. We do not accept content from community members, but we welcome blog posts by Red Hatters and Red Hat partners about Red Hat-supported open source projects.

We welcome contributions from Red Hatters and trusted partners and customers that discuss Red Hat products, services, and related open source projects.

### **Q: What happened to the Digital Communities (Enable Sysadmin, Enable Architect, Opensource.com, and The Enterprisers Project)?**  {#q:-what-happened-to-the-digital-communities-(enable-sysadmin,-enable-architect,-opensource.com,-and-the-enterprisers-project)?}

The Digital Communities team was affected by the layoffs that occurred in April 2023\. Opensource.com and enterprisersproject.com will remain online indefinitely as Red Hat web properties, receiving minimal viable support from the Digital Experience team. 

* **April 2023:** Elimination of persona-based community publications: Enable Sysadmin, Enable Architect, Opensource.com, and The Enterprisers Project  
* **December 2023:** Migration of [cloud.redhat.com/blog](http://cloud.redhat.com/blog) to [redhat.com/blog](http://redhat.com/blog)   
* **January 2024:** Migration of [ansible.com/blog](http://ansible.com/blog) to [redhat.com/blog](http://redhat.com/blog)  
* **February 2024:** Formation of cross-functional content review team to route blog submissions to [redhat.com/blog](http://redhat.com/blog), [developers.redhat.com/blog](http://developers.redhat.com/blog), [cloud.redhat.com/learn](http://cloud.redhat.com/learn), and knowledgebase  
* **April 2024:** Launch of redesigned [redhat.com/blog](http://redhat.com/blog) to include podcasts and videos and follow a topic-based content approach  
* **July 2024:** Completion of [user research analysis](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1von--aXLfhQ_tdTK9ejIN-mSGztY6tCLB2RIhiWOdis/edit?pli=1#slide=id.p) with recommendations  
* **September 2024:** Launch a proactive, transparent, collaborative approach to blog planning
